stanza.line: Shall I compare thee to a summer's (a)day(/a)
Thou art more lovely and more (b)temperate(/b)
Rough winds do shake the darling buds of (a)May(/a)
And summer's lease hath all too short a (b)date(/b)
Sometime too hot the eye of heaven (c)shines(/c)
And often is his gold complexion (d)dimmed(/d)
And every fair from fair sometime (c)declines(/c)
By chance or nature's changing course (d)untrimmed(/d)
But thy eternal summer shall not (e)fade(/e)
Nor lose possession of that fair thou (f)ow'st(/f)
Nor shall death brag thou wand'rest in his (e)shade(/e)
When in eternal lines to time thou (f)grow'st(/f)
So long as men can breathe or eyes can (g)see(/g)
So long lives this and this gives life to (g)thee(/g)
